Religious belief systems usually include the idea of divine will and divine [[Last Judgment|judgment]] and usually correspond to a moral code of conduct, and many religions claim that religion and morality are intimately connected. For example, the [[Roman Catholic Church]] maintains that although morality can be derived from unaided reason as it is simply the "right ordering" of man's actions, ultimately it derives from God because God created man and nature and that the ultimate sanction for immorality is the loss of a relationship with God.<ref>{{CathEncy|wstitle=Morality}}</ref>
    −
The Bible claims its morality is based on spiritual joy. Jesus says He commands people to love because that is what brings joy.<sup>John 15:11</sup> The Apostles Paul and John likewise state their purpose is to help people's joy.<sup>II Cor. 1:24, I John 1:4</sup> The Bible also claims God is good because His divine commands are reasonable; they are meant to fill us with joy.<sup>Isa. 1:18</sup> Furthermore it claims God works within us making us want to do what is moral.<sup>Phil. 2:13</sup> The Bible's New Testament covenant for eternal life demands following the moral code written into our minds,<sup>Heb. 10:16</sup> which is also known as the voice of Jesus,<sup>John 10:27</sup> and the human conscience.<sup>I Pet. 3:21</sup> The Biblical morality gives rise to the often accurate saying, "When I do good I feel good, when I do bad I feel bad."
+
The Bible claims its morality is based on spiritual joy. Jesus says He commands people to love because that is what brings joy.<ref>John 15:11</ref> The Apostles Paul and John likewise state their purpose is to help people's joy.<ref>II Cor. 1:24, I John 1:4</ref> The Bible also claims God is good because His divine commands are reasonable; they are meant to fill us with joy.<ref>Isa. 1:18</ref> Furthermore it claims God works within us making us want to do what is moral.<ref>Phil. 2:13</ref> The Bible's New Testament covenant for eternal life demands following the moral code written into our minds,<ref>Heb. 10:16</ref> which is also known as the voice of Jesus,<ref>John 10:27</ref> and the human conscience.<ref>I Pet. 3:21</ref> Because this moral code is based on receiving spiritual joy when doing acts of mercy,<ref>Matt. 9:13</ref> the Biblical morality often coincides with the saying, "When I do good I feel good, when I do bad I feel bad."<ref>Psalms 51:12</ref>
−
